questions.text: Epiglottis develops from
questions.solution:
Epiglottis develops from the Hypobranchial eminence.

 

Related Pearl: Development of Larynx

Part

Derivatives

2nd arch 

Upper part of the body of hyoid bone, lesser cornu of hyoid bone, stylohyoid ligament

3rd  arch

Lower part of the body of hyoid bone and greater cornua

4th arch

Upper part of thyroid cartilage

6th arch 

Lower part of thyroid cartilage, cricoid cartilage, corniculate cartilage, cuneiform cartilage, intrinsic muscles of larynx

questions.text: Most common congenital cause of stridor is
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia (congenital laryngeal stridor).

  • It is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx.
  • It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis.
  • On examination: OMEGA shaped epiglottis is seen.

questions.text: Sensory supply of larynx below the level of vocal cord is
questions.solution: Above the vocal cords, larynx is supplied by internal laryngeal nerve—a branch of superior laryngeal, and below the vocal cords by recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: Trotter’s triad is seen in
questions.solution:
Nasopharyngeal cancer can cause:

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube block)
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal/facial neuralgia (involvement of CN V) and
  • Palatal paralysis (CN X)

This is collectively called Trotter’s triad.

questions.text: False about the following is

choices.text: Also known as elephantiasis of nose
Seen in long standing cases of acne rosacea

questions.solution:
This is an image of Rhinophyma or potato tumor or elephantiasis:

  • It is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland.
  • Associated with long standing cases of acne rosacea in men past middle age.
  • Mostly seen at tip of nose and causes unsightly appearance and obstruction to breathing and vision.
  • Treatment: Excision with cauterization of base.

questions.text: Tripod fracture is a fracture of
questions.solution:
Tripod fracture is a fracture of zygoma.

Tripod fracture: After nasal bones, zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone. Zygoma is separated at its three processes. Fracture line passes through zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of maxillary sinus and the zygomaticotemporal suture.

questions.text: The following is useful in
questions.solution:
The above is a thudicum nasal speculum.

It is used to part the ala so as to visualize the anterior part of the nasal cavity. Structures visualized on Anterior rhinoscopy are:

  • Septum
  • Lateral wall (Middle and inferior turbinate)
  • Floor

Posterior rhinoscopy is done using a St. Clair Thompson’s Posterior rhinoscopy mirror through the oral cavity.

Endoscopy is done using Endoscopes of varying angles.

questions.text: Invagination of which of the following structures will form the external auditory meatus?
questions.solution:
Invagination of the first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the external auditory meatus.

Previously, it was believed that the external auditory meatus develops from the first pharyngeal cleft. But recent studies suggest that the first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the external auditory meatus.

Related Pearl: Embryology of the ear

Structures of the ear Embryological origin
Auricle or pinna 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch
External auditory meatus 1st pharyngeal arch
Tympanic membrane All 3 germ layers
Malleus and incus 1st pharyngeal arch
Stapes suprastructure 2nd pharyngeal arch
Stapes footplate and annular ligament Otic capsule
Tympanic cavity 1st pharyngeal pouch
Eustachian tube 1st pharyngeal pouch
Membranous labyrinth Otic vesicle
Semicircular canals and utricle Pars superior
Saccule and cochlea Pars inferior

questions.text: A middle-aged retropositive woman presented with complaints of hearing her own voice and breath sounds with ear fullness. She has lost significant weight in the past 6 months. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes autophony which is seen patulous eustachian tube.

Autophony is a symptom where the patient hears his own voice and breath sounds. 

Patulous eustachian tube is usually idiopathic where the tube is abnormally patent. But it is also seen in rapid weight loss, pregnancy especially the third trimester and patients with multiple sclerosis.

Treatment includes weight gain, administration of potassium iodide solution. In long-standing cases, specific treatment could include cauterization of tubes or insertion of the grommet.

Option A: In HIV-related psychosis, there will be persecutory delusion, hallucination, and no ear fullness.

Option B: The autophony of superior canal dehiscence syndrome usually involves hearing their own voice but not their breathing when compared with patients who have patulous eustachian tube.

Option D: Patient with blocked eustachian tube does not present with autophony.

questions.text: Which of the following attains adult size before birth?
questions.solution:
Ear ossicles attain adult size before birth. 

The development of the middle ear:

  • The ossicles are full-sized cartilage models by 15 weeks of gestation.
  • Endochondral ossification is complete by 25 weeks.
  • The middle ear is adult-sized at birth.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the tympanic membrane?
questions.solution:
The tympanic membrane has a thickness of 0.1mm.

The dimensions of the tympanic membrane are

  • Length: 9-10mm
  • Width: 8-9mm
  • Area: 90 mm2
  • Subtends an angle of 55° with horizontal 

The medial (inner) surface is convex and the lateral surface is concave. The most depressed part of its concavity is called the umbo, to which the tip of the malleus is attached.

Image: Right tympanic membrane

questions.text: A child with hearing difficulty is diagnosed to have glue ear. Which of the following is not a possible sequela of this condition?
questions.solution:
Otosclerosis is not a possible sequela of glue ear. Otosclerosis is a hereditary disease of the bone of the inner ear, which mostly affects the stapes footplate area. It is not related to other ear pathologies.

The sequelae of long-standing glue ear include:

  • Atrophy of tympanic membrane (TM) and myringosclerosis (fibrosis of TM)
  • Atelectasis of middle ear - when the tympanic membrane gets retracted over the promontory
  • Ossicular necrosis
  • Tympanosclerosis - collagen deposits within the middle ear
  • Retraction pockets in TM and cholesteatoma
  • Cholesterol granulomas - due to stasis of secretions in the mastoid and middle ear

questions.text: The organ of Corti is situated over which membrane?
questions.solution:
The organ of Corti is situated over the basilar membrane in scala media.

The membranes of the cochlear duct:

  • The basilar membrane sepearates scala media from tympani and supports the organ of Corti.
  • Reissner’s membrane seperates scala media from scala vestibuli.
  • Stria vascularis is the lateral part of scala media which secretes endolymph.

Shrapnell’s membrane is another name for pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of hearing loss in children?
questions.solution:
Otitis media with effusion, or glue ear, is the most common cause of hearing loss in children.

Clinical features of glue ear include:

  • Bilateral, painless, and fluctuating hearing loss. Conductive hearing loss not more than 40 dB is observed.
  • Defective and delayed development of speech.
  • Occasional mild earaches are present.

questions.text: Reinke’s space is seen in
questions.solution:
Reinke’s space is a potential space underneath the epithelium of vocal cords therefore the glottis.

It contains scanty subepithelial connective tissue.

Oedema of this space is commonly seen in smokers and is called reinke’s edema/ smoker’s larynx.

questions.text: What are petechiae?

choices.text: Large extravasation of blood in the skin

questions.solution:
Petechiae are defined as skin hemorrhages appearing as minute non-blanching spots that measure less than 2 mm.

A few conditions causing petechiae have been stated below:

  • Infectious diseases: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, infective endocarditis, meningococcemia, and viral hemorrhagic fevers.
  • Non-infectious conditions: Vasculitis, thrombocytopenia, leukemia, scurvy, and vitamin K deficiency
  • Drugs: Anticoagulants (warfarin, heparin), quinine, etc.

Large extravasation of blood in the skin is known as ecchymosis. 

Purpura are also non-blanching spots but unlike petechiae, they measure ≥ 3 mm in size.

questions.text: Grisel syndrome is
questions.solution:
Grisel syndrome:

It is one of the complications of adenoidectomy

Patient complains of neck pain and develops torticollis

Mostly it is due to spasm of paraspinal muscles, but can be due to atlantoaxial dislocation requiring cervical collar and even traction.

questions.text: Turbinate which articulates with ethmoid
questions.solution:
• Inferior turbinate is a separate bone and articulates with ethmoid.
  • Middle and Superior turbinates (and Supreme) are part of ethmoid bone.

questions.text: Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are characteristic of
questions.solution:
• Granulomatous Disease of nose
  • Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis
  • Biopsy shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies. The latter two are diagnostic features of the disease.
    • Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli.
    • Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. They occur due to accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by the plasma cells.
  • The causative organisms can be cultured from the biopsy material.

Rhinoscleroma with Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies:

 

Russell Bodies:

questions.text: Samter’s triad is related to
questions.solution:
Samter’s triad is associated with etiology of ethmoidal polyp. It consists of

  • nasal polypi
  • asthma and
  • aspirin intolerance

Other etiological factors of ethmoidal polyp:

  • Chronic rhinosinusitis especially NARES- non allergic rhinitis with eosiniphilia syndrome.
  • Asthma
  • Aspirin intolerance – Samter’s triad i.e. nasal polyp, asthma, aspirin intolerance.
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Allergic fungal sinusitis
  • Kartagener syndrome - This consists of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus and ciliary dyskinesis.
  • Young syndrome. It consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia.
  • Churg–Strauss syndrome. Consists of asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis and granuloma.
  • Nasal mastocytosis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of otomycosis?
questions.solution: Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the ear canal that often occurs due to Aspergillus niger (most common), Aspergillus fumigatus, or Candida albicans.

questions.text: Ceruminous glands are modifications of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ceruminous glands are modified apocrine sweat glands.

Ceruminous and sebaceous glands open into the space of the hair follicle in the external auditory canal.

questions.text: What is the length of external auditory canal?
questions.solution:
The length of the external auditory canal is about 24 mm.

It extends from the bottom of the concha to the tympanic membrane. It has two parts:

  • Outer cartilaginous part - 8mm
  • Inner bony part- 16mm

Related Pearl: External Auditory Canal

Part Cartilaginous Bony
Proportions Lateral 1/3 Medial 2/3
Length 8mm 16mm
Made of Auricular yellow elastic cartilage Bony margins of the temporal bone (squamous part superiorly and mastoid part posteriorly)
Direction Upward, backward, medially Downward, forward, medially
Skin is Thick Thin, continuous over tympanic membrane
Skin contains Hair, ceruminous & pilosebaceous glands. Produce wax ---
Deficiencies Fissures of Santorini Foramen of Huschke

questions.text: Most common site of origin of acoustic neuroma is____
questions.solution: Acoustic neuroma is a schwannoma more commonly arising from the superior and the inferior division of the vestibular nerve (60–80 percent) in the medial internal auditory canal at the site of transition of central to peripheral myelin i.e. Obersteiner-Redlich zone.

questions.text: Which of the following structures forms the promontory?
questions.solution:
The basal turn of the cochlea forms the promontory. 

The promontory is a bulge in the middle ear's medial wall, which is formed by the labyrinth.

It gives 2 extensions:

  • Subiculum below to the round window.
  • Ponticulus to the posterior wall.

questions.text: Angular movements are sensed by
questions.solution:
Semicircular canals respond to angular acceleration and deceleration. The receptors are the cristae, located in the ampullated ends of the three semicircular ducts.

Their utricle and saccule which contain macula, are stimulated by linear acceleration and deceleration or gravitational pull during the head tilts.

questions.text: A first-year ENT postgraduate sees a child with permanent perforation of the tympanic membrane.  Which of the following is a feature of such perforation?

choices.text: It is seen in acute suppurative otitis media
It is caused by necrotizing otitis externa
It has squamous epithelium at its edges
Medical management can be tried initially

questions.solution:
A permanent perforation is lined by squamous epithelium at its edges, hindering spontaneous healing.

Features of a permanent perforation:

  • Seen in chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM)
  • Is similar to an epithelial lined fistulous tract
  • Cannot be medically managed, thus mandating surgery

questions.text: Closure of glottis is by all except
questions.solution: Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only abductor of the vocal cord. Hence it opens the glottis. All other muscles close the glottis.

questions.text: 1 yr old boy presents with biphasic stridor, barking cough and difficulty in breathing and fever. Image given below depicts his Xray findings. All of the following are true about this condition except_____________

choices.text: Most common in age group of 6 months to 3 years
Most common organism responsible is Parainfluenza virus

questions.solution:
The clinical picture of biphasic stridor, barking cough and difficulty in breathing, and fever in the child along with the steeple sign on x ray, is suggestive of croup or laryngotracheobronchitis. Biphasic stridor suggests subglottic involvement (not supraglottis).

Croup or laryngotracheobronchitis is an inflammatory condition of the larynx, trachea, and bronchi caused by the parainfluenza virus (Option D). It is characterized by the subglottic swelling of loose areolar tissue leading to respiratory obstruction and stridor. It commonly affects children between 6 months and 3 years of age, more often male children. (Option A and B)

Laryngotracheobronchitis is characterized by a barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor. Agitation and crying aggravate the symptoms and signs. A hoarse voice, coryza, normal to moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate can be revealed in the physical examination. The upper airway obstruction may progress and the child can present with an increased respiratory rate, nasal flaring; suprasternal, infrasternal, and intercostal retractions; and continuous stridor. On X-ray a Steeple/Church top/pencil top sign (obstruction in subglottis) is seen.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: Passavant’s ridge is formed by
questions.solution:
Passavant’s Ridge

  • It is a mucosal ridge raised by fibres of palatopharyngeus.
  • It encircles the posterior and lateral walls of nasopharyngeal isthmus.
  • Soft palate, during its contraction, makes firm contact with this ridge to cut off nasopharynx from the oropharynx during the deglutition or speech.

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to the middle meatus
questions.solution:
Nasolacrimal duct opens into inferior meatus.

  • Agger nasi -It is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinate and meatus. When pneumatised and enlarged it encroaches on frontal recess area and causes mechanical obstruction to drainage of frontal sinus leading to sinusitis.
  • Maxillary sinus drains into the middle meatus. The ostium lies in the infundibulum.
  • Anterosuperiorly, frontal sinus also opens into infundibulum through frontal recess or frontonasal duct.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: Killian’s incision is used in
questions.solution:
Killian’s incision : SMR

Freer’s incision: Septoplasty

Killian’s incision is used in submucous resection. It is given 1.25cm behind the columella at the mucocutaneous junction at the convex side of deflection.

Freer’s hemitransfixation incision is used in septoplasty. It is given at the caudal end of the septum, usually on the concave side of the cartilage.

questions.text: Ringertz tumor is
questions.solution:
• Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumour or Schneiderian papilloma.
  • It is a premalignant locally invasive disease with a tendency to grow inwards. Hence the name.
  • Basal cell carcinoma is also known as rodent ulcer.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of nasal cavity arising from nasal septum is called nose picker’s cancer.
  • Esthesioneuroblastoma is also known as olfactory neuroblastoma or olfactory placode tumour as it arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper third of nose.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The otoscopic picture of both the tympanic membranes shows the Schwartze sign. This finding along with the history of bilateral conductive deafness is seen in active otosclerosis.

A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile.

Option A: Rising sun sign is seen in glomus tumor.

Option C: Setting sun sign is an eye sign seen in hydrocephalus.

Option D: Cartwheel appearance is seen in acute suppurative otitis media.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would you expect to observe the light-house effect?
questions.solution:
The light-house effect is seen in acute mastoiditis, which is a complication of otitis media. This effect is described as a pulsatile mucopurulent or purulent discharge, coming through a central pin-hole perforation of pars tensa. This suggests a reservoir of infection in the mastoid and middle ear.

Note: Otoscopic signs in intratympanic glomus tumors include:

  • Red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane
  • Pulsation sign or Brown sign - when ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel’s speculum, the tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches

questions.text: Recruitment is a feature of
questions.solution:
• Recruitment phenomenon is seen in cochlear pathology like Meniere’s disease.
  • This is the reason why patients with Meniere’s have an intolerance to loud sound.
  • Acoustic neuroma is a retrocochlear pathology; ASOM and CSOM cause conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: Which part of middle ear is formed by tegmen tympani?
questions.solution:
The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the middle ear.

It separates the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa.

It also extends posteriorly to form the roof of the aditus and antrum as tegmen mastoidea.

The following images shows the tegmen tympani and relations of middle ear:

questions.text: A patient has undergone a high-resolution CT of the temporal bone which confirmed a diagnosis of semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome. Which of the following will not be affected?
questions.solution:
The medial semicircular canal does not exist.

The semicircular canals are part of the bony labyrinth. They house the semicircular ducts which are the end organs for angular momentum.

They are 3 in number:

  • Superior also called anterior in the X-axis
  • Posterior in Y-axis
  • Lateral also called horizontal in Z-axis.

Semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome is an inner ear abnormality where the bony covering of the semicircular canals is very thin or absent. It usually affects the superior semicircular canal but can rarely involve the posterior or lateral semicircular canals. The superior semicircular canal is present inferior to the arcuate eminence of the temporal bone.

questions.text: A child with protruding ears is brought to the OPD by his worried parents. They opt for surgical correction of the defect due to cosmetic reasons. After what age would you proceed with the surgery?
questions.solution:
Protruding ears or bat ears can be corrected anytime after 6 years of age if cosmetic appearance demands. This is due to the fact that the pinna is completely developed and achieves adult configuration by the age of 6 years.

Protruding ears are caused by a large concha with poorly developed antihelix and scapha.

Related Pearl: Congenital anomalies of pinna

Condition

Abnormality

Microtia

Small pinna

Anotia

Absent pinna and stenosis of outer EAC

Bat ear

Absent anti-helix

Mozart ear

Fusion of helix & antihelix

Wildermuth ear

Absent helix

Macrotia

Large pinna

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the atticoantral type of chronic suppurative otitis media?

choices.text: Involvement of Shrapnell's membrane is seen

questions.solution:
Atticoantral type also called unsafe or dangerous type involves perforation of Shrapnell's membrane or pars flaccida (attic perforation). 

The disease is often associated with a bone-eroding process such as cholesteatoma, granulations, or osteitis. The risk of complications is high in this variety.

Related Pearl: Classification of CSOM

  Tubo-tympanic Attico-antral
Old name Safe type Unsafe ear
Recent name Mucosal variant Squamosal disease

Profuse

Mucoid

Non-blood stained

Scanty

Purulent

Foul-smelling

May be blood stained
Site Mostly in the pro-tympanum, i.e., part of middle ear around the Eustachian tube orifice Mostly involves the epi-tympanum/attic and involves the mastoid antrum via the aditus
Perforation Central (most common: Antero-inferior quadrant)

Attic (Pars flaccida) or

Marginal (most common: Postero-superior)

Polyp Pale, rare Fleshy red, common
Cholesteatoma Absent Present
Complications Rare Common
Treatment Medical/ surgical (Tympanoplasty) Always surgical (Mastoidectomy)

questions.text: The following is true regarding attachments of arytenoid except:
questions.solution:
The apex of the arytenoid supports the corniculate cartilages.

The following are the attachments of the arytenoid:

  • Base - cricoid
  • Vocal process- Vocal ligament
  • Muscular process- intrinsic muscles of larynx
  • Apex- corniculate cartilages

questions.text: All of  the following are seen in TB larynx except
questions.solution:
TB larynx findings –

  • Swelling in the interarytenoid region giving a mamillated appearance. Ulceration of vocal cord giving mouse-nibbled appearance.
  • Pseudoedema of the epiglottis “turban epiglottis.” 
  •  Thumb sign seen on lat neck X-ray in epiglottitis.

questions.text: Frog face deformity is seen in
questions.solution:
Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma

  • It is a benign highly vascular tumor of adolescent boys.
  • Locally invasive.
  • It spreads to the orbits giving rise to proptosis and widening of the intercanthal distance leading to “frog-face deformity.”

questions.text: Onodi cells and haller cells are in relation to

choices.text: Optic nerve and roof of maxillary sinus

questions.solution:
Onodi cell is related to optic nerve and haller cell is related to maxillary sinus.

Onodi cell (sphenoethmoidal cell) is a posterior ethmoidal cell extending into sphenoid sinus. It is surgically important as the optic nerve and internal carotid artery may be related to its lateral wall.

Haller cell (infraorbital ethmoidal air cell) is an anterior ethmoidal air cell that pneumatizes into the roof of maxillary sinus (orbital floor) above the maxillary sinus ostium.

questions.text: Bony septal perforation occurs in
questions.solution:
Chronic granulomatous conditions like lupus, tuberculosis and leprosy cause perforation in the cartilaginous part.

Bony perforation is only seen in syphilis.

questions.text: A  male child presents with unilateral foul smelling blood-stained nasal discharge for 5 days. CT scan is as follows. Diagnosis is_________
questions.solution:
This is a case of rhinolith. The first differential for a unilateral foul smelling discharge in children is a forgotten/unknown foreign body. Overtime this foreign body develops a reaction around it giving it a false envelop that calcifies and erodes surrounding structures causing bleeding and discharge.

Other options:

  • JNA is seen in adolescent boys and is a soft tissue mass in the nasopharynx.
  • Meningoencephalocoele is a soft tissue mass entering the nose from the skull base.
  • Osteoma is not commonly seen on the floor and would be in continuation with a normal bone.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding otosclerosis?

choices.text: Females are affected twice as often as males.
Stapedotomy should be avoided in children.
HRCT shows double ring sign in stapedial otosclerosis.
It may be associated with measles.

questions.solution:
HRCT shows the double-ring sign in cochlear otosclerosis, not in the stapedial type.

Otosclerosis affects females twice as often as males. But in India, otosclerosis seems to predominate in males.

Stapedotomy is contraindicated in children because recurrent eustachian tube dysfunction is common in them. This can displace the prosthesis or cause acute otitis media. 

Measles RNA has been found in otosclerotic foci implicating its possible role in pathogenesis.

questions.text: Glycerol test is done in
questions.solution:
Glycerol test is done in Meniere's disease.

Glycerol is a dehydrating agent. When given orally, it reduces endolymph pressure and thus causes an improvement in hearing. The test has a diagnostic and prognostic value. These days, glycerol test is combined with electrocochleography.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the OPD with fever, earache, and poor feeding after an episode of URTI. You suspect this as acute suppurative otitis media due to an eustachian tube defect. Which is the most accurate test to detect this?
questions.solution:
Tympanometry is the most accurate test to assess eustachian tube (ET) dysfunction. It is an objective measure of ET function and does not rely on patient cooperation.

In this test, the movement of TM is visualized to the variation in external canal pressure. The disadvantage is middle ear pathologies can overshadow ET function.

 

Related Pearl: Valsalva vs. Toynbee

 

Valsalva

Toynbee

Maneuver

Blow with closed nose & mouth

Swallow with closed nose & mouth

Pressure build-up in the nasopharynx

Positive

Negative

Test of

ET patency

ET function

Result on TM

TM moves out

TM moves inwards/ retracts

Contraindications

Atrophic TM

Acute infections in the nose and pharynx

Atrophic TM

questions.text: Which of the following is the shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve?
questions.solution:
The shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve is the labyrinthine segment (length 4.0 mm, diameter 0.61–0.68 mm).

The labyrinthine segment is from the fundus of meatus to the geniculate ganglion where the nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a genu. The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter  and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest. Thus edema or inflammation can easily compress the nerve and cause paralysis.

Related Pearl: Parts of Intratemporal Division of Facial Nerve

Segment Within From To Length (mm) Remarks
Meatal Internal Acoustic Meatus Porus acousticus (medial end of IAM) Fundus (lateral end of IAM) 8-10 Only intra-temporal segment that is not within fallopian canal
Labyrinthine Fallopian canal Fundus 1st genu/ geniculate ganglion 3-5 Shortest and the narrowest
Tympanic/ Horizontal Fallopian canal 1st genu 2nd genu 11 Runs on medial wall of middle ear
Mastoid/ Vertical Fallopian canal 2nd genu Stylomastoid foramen 13 Runs in posterior wall of middle ear
